Items.Title: Azure Arc-enabled app services
Items.Description: The deployment scenarios in this section will guide you through deploying and working with Azure Arc-enabled app services on multiple infrastructure platforms.

Items.Title: Azure Kubernetes Service
Items.Description: If you do not yet have a Kubernetes cluster, the scenarios in this section will guide on creating an AKS cluster with Azure Arc-enabled app services integration in an automated fashion using ARM templates.

Items.Title: Azure API Management Gateway ARM Template
Kubernetes Cluster API
Items.Description: If you do not yet have a Kubernetes cluster, the scenarios in this section will guide on deploying Azure Arc-enabled app services on Cluster API (CAPI) Kubernetes in an automated fashion using ARM templates.

Items.Title: Azure API Management Gateway ARM Template
Azure Arc-enabled data services
Items.Description: The deployment scenarios in this section will guide you through deploying and working with Azure Arc-enabled data services on multiple infrastructure platforms.

Items.Title: Azure Kubernetes Service
Items.Description: If you do not yet have a Kubernetes cluster, the scenarios in this section will guide on creating an AKS cluster with Azure Arc-enabled data services integration in an automated fashion using ARM templates.

Items.Title: Azure Red Hat OpenShift
Items.Description: If you do not yet have an Azure Red Hat OpenShift cluster, the scenarios in this section will guide on creating an ARO cluster with Azure Arc-enabled data services integration in an automated fashion using ARM templates.

Items.Title: Kubernetes Cluster API
Items.Description: If you do not yet have a Kubernetes cluster, the scenarios in this section will guide on deploying Azure Arc-enabled data services on Cluster API (CAPI) Kubernetes in an automated fashion using ARM templates.

Items.Title: Unified Operations Use Cases
Items.Description: Once you have your Azure Arc-enabled data services deployed, you can start to use native Azure tooling to manage it as well explore various architecture and deployment models.

Items.Description: If you are working in a multi-cloud environment, the scenario in this section will guide on creating an Amazon Elastic Kubernetes Service (EKS) with Azure Arc-enabled data services integration in an automated fashion using Terraform.

Items.Title: Google Kubernetes Engine
Items.Description: If you are working in a multi-cloud environment, the scenario in this section will guide on creating a Google Kubernetes Engine (GKE) with Azure Arc-enabled data services integration in an automated fashion using Terraform.

Items.Title: Kubernetes Kubeadm
Items.Description: If you do not have a Kubernetes cluster, the scenarios in this section will guide on how to create a Kubernetes cluster using kubeadm in Azure VMs with Azure Arc-enabled data services integration in an automated fashion using ARM template.

Items.Title: MicroK8s
Items.Description: If you do not yet have a Kubernetes cluster, the scenarios in this section will guide on deploying Azure Arc-enabled data services on Microk8s in an automated fashion using ARM templates.

Items.Title: Azure Arc-enabled Kubernetes
Items.Description: The deployment scenarios in this section will guide you through onboarding various Kubernetes distributions as an Azure Arc-enabled Kubernetes clusters.

Items.Title: Azure Kubernetes Service (AKS)
Items.Description: If you do not yet have a Kubernetes cluster, the scenarios in this section will guide on creating an AKS cluster in order to simulate an "on-premises" cluster in an automated fashion using either ARM template or Terraform.

Items.Title: Azure Kubernetes Service (AKS) hybrid
Items.Description: Azure Kubernetes Service (AKS) hybrid deployment options ("AKS hybrid") is an on-premises implementation. The scenarios in this section will guide on creating an AKS hybrid cluster in order to simulate an "on-premises" cluster in an automated fashion.

Items.Title: Discover ONVIF cameras with Akri on AKS Edge Essentials multi-node deployment
AKS Edge Essentials single node deployment
Discover ONVIF cameras with Akri on AKS Edge Essentials single node deployment

Alibaba Cloud Container Service for Kubernetes
Items.Description: If you are working in a multi-cloud environment, the scenario in this section will guide on creating a Alibaba Cloud Container Service for Kubernetes and onboard it as an Azure Arc-enabled Kubernetes cluster in an automated fashion using Terraform.

Azure Red Hat OpenShift
Items.Description: If you do not yet have an Azure Red Hat OpenShift cluster, the scenarios in this section will guide you on how to create an Azure-managed OpenShift cluster in an automated fashion and onboard it as an Azure Arc-enabled Kubernetes cluster.

Items.Title: Kubernetes Cluster API
Items.Description: If you are working in a multi-cloud environment, the scenarios in this section will guide on creating clusters using Kubernetes Cluster API (CAPI) and onboard it as an Azure Arc-enabled Kubernetes cluster in an automated fashion.

Items.Title: Unified Operations Use Cases
Items.Description: Once you have Kubernetes clusters projected into Azure with Azure Arc, you can start to use native Azure tooling to manage the clusters as native Azure resources. The following scenarios show examples of using Cluster extensions and Azure management tools such as Azure Monitor, GitOps configurations, and Azure Policy.

Items.Title: Deploy GitOps configurations and perform basic GitOps flow on AKS as an Azure Arc Connected Cluster (Flux v2)
Deploy GitOps configurations and perform Helm-based GitOps flow on AKS as an Azure Arc Connected Cluster (Flux v2)
Integrate Azure Monitor for Containers with AKS as an Azure Arc Connected Cluster using a Shell script
Apply GitOps configurations on AKS as an Azure Arc Connected Cluster using Azure Policy for Kubernetes
Deploy GitOps configurations and perform basic GitOps flow on AKS on Azure Stack HCI as an Azure Arc Connected Cluster
Deploy GitOps configurations and perform Helm-based GitOps flow on AKS on Azure Stack HCI as an Azure Arc Connected Cluster
Integrate Azure Monitor for Containers with AKS on Azure Stack HCI as an Azure Arc Connected Cluster using cluster extensions
Integrate Microsoft Defender for Cloud with Cluster API as an Azure Arc Connected Cluster using Kubernetes extensions
Deploy GitOps configurations and perform basic GitOps flow on Cluster API as an Azure Arc Connected Cluster (Flux v2)
Deploy GitOps configurations and perform Helm-based GitOps flow on Cluster API as an Azure Arc Connected Cluster (Flux v2)
Integrate Azure Key Vault with Cluster API as an Azure Arc Connected Cluster using Kubernetes extensions
Integrate Open Service Mesh (OSM) with Cluster API as an Azure Arc Connected Cluster using Kubernetes extensions
Deploy GitOps configurations and perform basic GitOps flow on GKE as an Azure Arc Connected Cluster (Flux v2)
Deploy GitOps configurations and perform Helm-based GitOps flow on GKE as an Azure Arc Connected Cluster (Flux v2)
Integrate Azure Monitor for Containers with GKE as an Azure Arc Connected Cluster using a Shell script
Integrate Azure Monitor for Containers with GKE as an Azure Arc Connected Cluster using cluster extensions
Apply GitOps configurations on GKE as an Azure Arc Connected Cluster using Azure Policy for Kubernetes
Deploy GitOps configurations and perform Helm-based GitOps flow on kind as an Azure Arc Connected Cluster
Deploy GitOps configurations and perform Helm-based GitOps flow on MicroK8s as an Azure Arc Connected Cluster (Flux v2)
Integrate Azure Monitor for Containers with MicroK8s as an Azure Arc Connected Cluster using a Shell script
Integrate Azure Policy with an Azure Arc-enabled Kubernetes cluster using extensions
Use Azure Policy Add-on to audit pods' labels for use with Calico network policy
Using Cluster Connect to connect to an Azure Arc-enabled Kubernetes cluster via service account token authentication
Integrate Azure Monitor Container Insights and recommended alerts with an Azure Arc-enabled Kubernetes cluster using extensions
Managing Calico Network Policy using GitOps in an Azure Arc-enabled Kubernetes cluster
Developer Use Cases
Items.Description: Once you onboarded your Azure Arc-enabled Kubernetes clusters, you can start to use native Azure tooling to manage the clusters as native Azure resources. The following scenarios show examples of using developer-centric use-cases.

Items.Title: Deploy an application using the Dapr Cluster extension for Azure Arc-enabled Kubernetes cluster
Amazon Elastic Kubernetes Service
Items.Description: If you are working in a multi-cloud environment, the scenario in this section will guide on creating an Amazon Elastic Kubernetes Service (EKS) and onboard it as an Azure Arc-enabled Kubernetes cluster in an automated fashion using Terraform.

Items.Title: Onboarding
Items.Description: This example demonstrates how to connect an existing Kubernetes cluster to Arc. It assumes you already have a cluster ready to work with.

Items.Title: Google Kubernetes Engine
Items.Description: If you are working in a multi-cloud environment, the scenario in this section will guide on creating a Google Kubernetes Engine (GKE) and onboard it as an Azure Arc-enabled Kubernetes cluster in an automated fashion using Terraform.

Items.Title: IoT Uses Cases
Items.Description: If you do not yet have a Kubernetes cluster, the scenarios in this section will guide you on using AKS as an Azure Arc-enabled Kubernetes cluster and simulate Azure IoT Edge environment in an automated fashion.

Items.Title: Azure IoT Edge integration with AKS as an Azure Arc Connected Cluster
Kind
Items.Description: If you do not have a Kubernetes cluster, the scenario in this section will guide on creating a kind (kubernetes in docker) cluster on your local machine and onboard it as an Azure Arc-enabled Kubernetes cluster in an automated fashion.

Items.Title: MicroK8s
Items.Description: If you do not have a Kubernetes cluster, the scenario in this section will guide on creating a MicroK8s Kubernetes cluster on your local machine and onboard it as an Azure Arc-enabled Kubernetes cluster in an automated fashion.

Items.Title: Platform9 Managed Kubernetes
Items.Description: The scenario in this section will guide on creating a Platform9 Managed Kubernetes (PMK) cluster on-premise or on the cloud and onboard it as an Azure Arc-enabled Kubernetes cluster in an automated fashion.

Items.Title: Rancher K3s
Items.Description: If you do not have a Kubernetes cluster, the scenarios in this section will guide on creating a Rancher K3s Kubernetes cluster on either your VMware vSphere infrastructure or on an Azure VM and onboard it as an Azure Arc-enabled Kubernetes cluster in an automated fashion using either ARM template or Terraform.

Items.Title: Azure Arc and Azure Lighthouse
Items.Description: This section describes how to use Azure Arc and Azure Lighthouse for unified operations.

Items.Title: Unified Operations at Scale with Azure Arc and Azure Lighthouse
Azure Arc-enabled machine learning
Items.Description: The deployment scenarios in this section will guide you through deploying and working with Azure Arc-enabled machine learning on Kubernetes.

Items.Title: Azure Kubernetes Service
Items.Description: If you do not yet have a Kubernetes cluster, the scenarios in this section will guide on creating an AKS cluster with Azure Arc-enabled machine learning in an automated fashion using ARM templates. The ML pipeline trains an image classification model on the MNIST dataset from Blob Storage, and deploys the trained model as an inference endpoint on the Kubernetes Cluster.

Items.Title: Image Classification on MNIST dataset from Blob Storage
Azure Arc-enabled servers
Items.Description: The deployment scenarios in this section will guide you through onboarding various Windows and Linux server distributions as Azure Arc-enabled servers.

Items.Title: Amazon Web Services
Items.Description: If you are working in a multi-cloud environment, you can deploy new AWS EC2 instances in an automated fashion using Terraform and onboard it as Azure Arc-enabled servers.

Items.Title: Microsoft Azure
Items.Description:
The scenarios in this section will walk you through how to project an Azure VM as an Azure Arc-enabled server in an automated fashion using either ARM templates or Terraform. These scenarios, using Azure VM as the targeted Azure Arc server are designed **for demo and testing purposes ONLY and are not supported.**
In each scenario, you will find a detailed, technical explanation of the mechanism and why **it is not expected to project an Azure VM as an Azure Arc-enabled server.**

Items.Title: Microsoft Azure Stack HCI
Items.Description:
The scenarios in this section will walk you through how to project an **Azure Stack HCI Virtual Machine** as an Azure Arc-enabled server in an automated fashion. 
In each scenario, you will find a detailed, technical explanation of the mechanism.

Items.Title: Unified Operations Use Cases
Items.Description: Once you have server resources projected into Azure with Azure Arc, you can start to use native Azure tooling to manage the servers as native Azure resources. The following scenarios show examples of using Azure management tools such as resource tags, Azure Policy, Log Analytics, and more with Azure Arc-enabled servers.

Items.Title: Enable Azure Automanage on an Azure Arc-enabled server using built-in profiles
Enable Azure Automanage on an Azure Arc-enabled server using custom profiles
Create Automanage Machine Configuration custom configurations for Linux
Create Automanage Machine Configuration custom configurations for Windows
Monitoring Azure Arc-enabled servers with Datadog
Using Azure Arc to deliver Extended Security Updates (ESU) for Windows Server 2012 and SQL Server 2012
Google Cloud Platform
Items.Description: If you are working in a multi-cloud environment, you can deploy new GCP instances in an automated fashion using Terraform and onboard it as Azure Arc-enabled servers.

Items.Title: Onboarding
Items.Description: The scenarios in this section can be used to onboard your existing Windows or Linux servers as Azure Arc-enabled servers.

Items.Title: Scaled Deployment
Items.Description: The scenarios in this section are designed to provide scaled onboarding experience to Azure Arc of virtual machines deployed in various platforms and existing environments.

Items.Title: AWS EC2 dynamic inventory with Ansible
Windows server with Configuration Manager using PowerShell
Windows server with Configuration Manager using a Task Sequence
HashiCorp Vagrant
Items.Description: If you don't have any existing servers available, the scenarios in this section will guide you on using HashiCorp Vagrant to host a new server locally in order to simulate an "on-premises" server and onboard it as an Azure Arc-enabled server.

Items.Title: VMware vSphere
Items.Description: If you are working with an on-premises VMware vSphere infrastructure, you can deploy new Windows or Linux virtual machines in an automated fashion using Terraform and onboard it as Azure Arc-enabled servers.

Items.Title: Azure Arc-enabled SQL Server
Items.Description: The deployment scenarios in this section will guide you through onboarding Microsoft SQL Server as an Azure Arc-enabled SQL server.

Items.Title: Amazon Web Services
Items.Description: If you are working in a multi-cloud environment, you can deploy new a AWS EC2 instance installed with SQL Server in an automated fashion using Terraform and onboard it as Azure Arc-enabled SQL Server.

Items.Title: Microsoft Azure
Items.Description:
The guides in this section will walk you through how to project an Azure VM installed with SQL Server as an Azure Arc-enabled server and Azure Arc-enabled SQL. This guide, using Azure VM as the targeted Azure Arc-enabled SQL Server, is designed **for demo and testing purposes ONLY and are not supported.** In the guide you will find a detailed technical explanation of the mechanism and why **it is not expected to project an Azure VM as an Azure Arc-enabled server.**
In each guide, you find a detailed, technical explanation of the mechanism and why it is not expected to project an Azure VM as an Azure Arc-enabled server.

Items.Title: SQL Server on Windows Server Virtual Machine
SQL Server Hyper-V Windows Virtual Machine
Unified Operations Use Cases
Items.Description: Once you have server resources projected into Azure with Azure Arc, you can start to use native Azure tooling to manage the servers as native Azure resources. The following scenarios show examples of using Azure management tools with Azure Arc-enabled SQL Server.

Items.Title: Using Azure Arc to deliver Extended Security Updates (ESU) for Windows Server 2012 and SQL Server 2012
Google Cloud Platform
Items.Description: If you are working in a multi-cloud environment, you can deploy new a GCP instance installed with SQL Server in an automated fashion using Terraform and onboard it as Azure Arc-enabled SQL Server.

Items.Title: VMware vSphere
Items.Description: If you are working with an on-premises VMware vSphere infrastructure, you can deploy new Windows Server virtual machine installed with SQL Server in an automated fashion using Terraform and onboard it as Azure Arc-enabled SQL Server.

Items.Title: Azure Arc-enabled VMware vSphere
Items.Description: The deployment scenarios in this section will guide you through how to manage VMware vSphere resources with Azure Arc.

Items.Title: Azure Arc-enabled VMware vSphere lifecycle
Items.Description: The deployment scenarios in this section will guide you through how to manage the lifecycle of VMware vSphere resources with Azure Arc.

Items.Title: Create a Windows VMware VM to an Azure Arc-enabled vSphere cluster using ARM templates
Azure Arc resource bridge deployment
Items.Description: The scenarios in this section will walk you through how to connect your VMware vCenter Server to Azure Arc using PowerShell.
